com.stormpath.sdk.servlet.client

Class ClientLoader

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.stormpath.sdk.servlet.client.ClientLoader
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    DefaultClientLoaderListener

    public class ClientLoader
extends Object
    A ClientLoader is responsible for loading a web application's Stormpath Client instance and making it available in the ServletContext at application startup. Once in the ServletContext, the Client is available to any application component that needs to interact with Stormpath; these components can can access the client instance easily, for example: 
     (Client)aServletRequest.getAttribute(Client.class.getName());

    Usage

    This implementation will, without any configuration at all, instantiate and use a DefaultServletContextClientFactory to build the Client used by the application. The DefaultServletContextClientFactory supports the following context-param options in your web.xml configuration: stormpathApiKeyFileLocation and stormpathClientAuthenticationScheme.

    stormpathApiKeyFileLocation

    The stormpathApiKeyFileLocation context-param, if present, allows you to specify the resource path to the apiKey.properties file that should be used to authenticate requests to Stormpath. For example:

     <context-param>
     <param-name>stormpathApiKeyFileLocation</param-name>
     <param-value>/users/whatever/stormpath/apiKey.properties</param-value>
 </context-param>

    You may load files from the filesystem, classpath, or URLs by prefixing the location path with file:, classpath:, or url: respectively. If no prefix is present, file: is assumed by default.

    If you do not specify this context-param, ${user.home}/.stormpath/apiKey.properties is assumed by default.

    stormpathClientAuthenticationScheme

    The stormpathClientAuthenticationScheme context-param, if present, allows you to specify a different HTTP authentication scheme than Stormpath's (very secure) default. At the moment, the only other alternative is basic. For example:

     <context-param>
     <param-name>stormpathClientAuthenticationScheme</param-name>
     <param-value>basic</param-value>
 </context-param>

    Because Stormpath's default authentication scheme is more secure than HTTP Basic authentication, it is strongly recommended that you do not override this value unless you have to. For example, Google App Engine users will be forced to specify basic here because GAE's outbound HTTP connection behavior interferes with the default algorithm. Again, it is not recommended that you use basic unless you have a technical limitation that prevents you from using Stormpath's default.

    If you do not specify this context-param, sauthc1 is assumed by default.

    Custom ServletContextClientFactory Implementation

    As mentioned above, the ClientLoader assumes the DefaultServletContextClientFactory behavior (supporting the above two context-param options) is sufficient for many needs. If you need to build your application's Client instance in a custom way - perhaps to enable specific CacheManager instance using a ClientBuilder - you can implement the ServletContextClientFactory interface yourself and specify that implementation class name as follows:

     <context-param>
     <param-name>stormpathServletContextClientFactoryClass</param-name>
     <param-value>com.mycompany.myapp.stormpath.MyCustomServletContextClientFactory</param-value>
 </context-param>

    If you do not specify this context-param, com.stormpath.sdk.servlet.client.DefaultServletContextClientFactory is assumed by default.

    Because the DefaultServletContextClientFactory implementation is basic and does not support specifying a custom CacheManager implementation, it is recommended that you create your own ServletContextClientFactory implementation and specify that class name here for more advanced use cases.

    Since:
    1.0.RC3
    See Also:
    ServletContextClientFactory, DefaultServletContextClientFactory

    • Method Detail

      • createClient

        public Client createClient(javax.servlet.ServletContext servletContext)
                    throws IllegalStateException
        Creates and initializes a Stormpath Client instance for the web application attributed to the specified ServletContext and assigns that instance to the ServletContext for that context's lifespan. The client instance is created by instantiating a ServletContextClientFactory implementation class, and the class name can be specified as a stormpathClientFactoryClass context parameter. If this parameter is not specified, the default DefaultServletContextClientFactory implementation is assumed.
        Parameters:
        servletContext - current servlet context
        Returns:
        the new Stormpath Client instance.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if an existing Client has already been initialized and associated with the specified ServletContext.

      • determineClientFactoryClass

        protected Class<?> determineClientFactoryClass(javax.servlet.ServletContext servletContext)
        Return the ServletContextClientFactory implementation class to use, either the default DefaultServletContextClientFactory or a custom class if specified.
        Parameters:
        servletContext - current servlet context
        Returns:
        the WebEnvironment implementation class to use
        See Also:
        CLIENT_FACTORY_CLASS_PARAM, DefaultServletContextClientFactory

      • doCreateClient

        protected Client doCreateClient(javax.servlet.ServletContext sc)
        Instantiates a Client based on the specified ServletContext.

        This implementation determines a ServletContextClientFactory implementation class to use. That class is instantiated, returned, and invoked.

        This allows custom ServletContextClientFactory implementations to be specified via a ServletContext init-param if desired. If not specified, the default DefaultServletContextClientFactory implementation will be used.

        Parameters:
        sc - current servlet context
        Returns:
        the constructed Stormpath client instance

      • destroyClient

        public void destroyClient(javax.servlet.ServletContext servletContext)
        Destroys the Client for the given servlet context.
        Parameters:
        servletContext - the ServletContext attributed to the WebSecurityManager
